content.title: Natural Units: Definition and Dimensional Relationships
content.summary: Natural units are unit systems where certain fundamental physical constants are set to unity by definition. This simplifies equations and reveals the underlying physics by removing conversion factors.

definition.statement: A natural unit system is defined by choosing fundamental constants to have the numerical value 1 (dimensionless).

planck_units.result: All mechanical quantities (mass, length, time, temperature) become equivalent dimensions

particle_physics_units.common_usage: Masses in GeV, lengths in GeV⁻¹

examples: Energy and momentum have same dimension

full_planck_units.implication: Everything dimensionless when measured in Planck units
examples: Length in ℓ_P, mass in m_P, time in t_P

advantages: Numerical calculations more intuitive in natural scales
cautions: Must track dimensions carefully when converting back to SI
Numerical factors may differ between conventions
